Package io.github.ai4ci.abm.inhost

Interface InHostModelState<CFG extends InHostConfiguration>

Type Parameters:
CFG - the type of in-host configuration used to initialize the model state
All Superinterfaces:
Serializable
All Known Subinterfaces:
InHostMarkovState, InHostPhenomenologicalState, InHostStochasticState
public interface InHostModelState<CFG extends InHostConfiguration> extends Serializable
Interface for in-host models that simulate viral dynamics, immune response, and disease progression over time within an individual.

All implementations must provide:

  • Normalized viral load,
  • Disease severity,
  • Immune activity,
  • Infection status,
  • A time counter,
  • A method to update the state given external exposures (virion or immunization).

This abstraction enables plug-and-play use of different in-host modeling approaches:

  • Phenomenological: continuous curves with superposition of exposures,
  • Stochastic difference equations: discrete compartments with binomial/Poisson transitions,
  • Markov state models: discrete states with probabilistic progression.

Biological and Statistical Foundation

The update and aggregation of infection risks across a population rely on two key probabilistic frameworks:

1. Set Coverage Problem When modeling exposure in networks or venues, the probability that a target cell or individual is infected after \( X \) random contacts is governed by coverage: \[ \mathbb{P}(\text{covered}) = 1 - \left(1 - \frac{1}{N}\right)^X \approx 1 - e^{-X/N} \] This determines the expected fraction of the population or cellular targets exposed after repeated random sampling.

See Also:
  • Set Coverage Problem

    2. Poisson Binomial Distribution In heterogeneous populations, the number of individuals transitioning between states (e.g., exposed → infectious) follows a Poisson binomial distribution, where each individual has a potentially different transition probability \( p_i \). The mean and variance are: \[ \mathbb{E}\left[\sum_i x_i\right] = \sum_i p_i, \quad \mathrm{Var}\left[\sum_i x_i\right] = \sum_i p_i(1 - p_i) \] This is critical for accurately simulating population-level outcomes without assuming homogeneity.

  • Poisson Binomial Distribution

    This interface ensures that regardless of the internal model, downstream components (e.g., transmission, calibration, severity mapping) can interact uniformly with the in-host state.

  • Method Details

    • test

      static <CFG extends InHostConfiguration> InHostModelState<CFG> test(CFG config, ExecutionConfiguration execConfig, Sampler rng)
      Factory method to create a test instance of the in-host model, useful for calibration and debugging.

      Uses DefaultPersonInitialiser to initialize the model with default parameters and a given random sampler. The time step is initialized to 0.

      Type Parameters:
      CFG - the type of in-host configuration
      Parameters:
      config - the in-host configuration specific to the model
      execConfig - the global execution configuration
      rng - the random sampler
      Returns:
      a newly initialized in-host model state

    • getImmuneActivity

      @NonAttribute double getImmuneActivity()
      Returns the level of active immune response, typically normalized to [0,1].

      This modulates:

      • Viral clearance rate,
      • Susceptibility to reinfection,
      • Disease severity.

      In some models, this is binary (0 or 1); in others, it is continuous and cumulative.

      Returns:
      immune activity level (0 = none, 1 = maximum)

    • getNormalisedSeverity

      @NonAttribute double getNormalisedSeverity()
      Returns a normalized severity score, typically in [0,1], representing clinical outcome.

      This may be derived from viral load, symptom state, or hospitalization status. It is used to map infection to observable events (e.g., hospitalization) with given probabilities. For example, if \( S \) is severity and \( r_h \) is the infection-hospitalization rate, then: \[ \mathbb{P}(\text{hospitalized}) = \mathbb{P}(S \gt 1 - r_h) \] ensuring population-level rates are preserved.

      Returns:
      normalized severity (0 = no disease, 1 = fatal)

    • getNormalisedViralLoad

      @NonAttribute double getNormalisedViralLoad()
      Returns the normalized viral load, typically scaled relative to a reference infectiousness threshold.

      This value is used in transmission models to compute the probability of infectious contact: \[ p_{\text{transmit}} \propto f(V_{\text{norm}}) \] where \( V_{\text{norm}} = V / V_{\text{cutoff}} \). The exact functional form depends on the model.

      Returns:
      normalized viral load (unitless, ≥ 0)

    • getTime

      int getTime()
      The time step counter for the in-host model, representing the number of updates since initialization.
      Returns:
      the current time step (integer, starting at 0)

    • update

      default InHostModelState<CFG> update(Person person, Sampler sampler)
      Convenience method to update the in-host state using exposure data from a Person.

      Extracts:

      • Total exposure from contact network,
      • Immunisation dose from vaccination history.

      Delegates to update(Sampler, double, double).

      Parameters:
      person - the person whose exposure and immunization history is used
      sampler - the random sampler
      Returns:
      updated in-host state

    • update

      InHostModelState<CFG> update(Sampler sampler, double virionExposure, double immunisationDose)
      Advances the in-host state by one time step, processing new exposures.

      The update incorporates:

      • virionExposure: external infectious dose (relative to infectious threshold),
      • immunisationDose: vaccine or booster exposure (may prime immunity),
      • sampler: source of randomness for stochastic transitions.

      The implementation determines how these inputs affect viral load, immunity, and disease state. All models must ensure state consistency and biological plausibility (e.g., no negative counts).

      Parameters:
      sampler - the random number generator for stochastic transitions
      virionExposure - the magnitude of external viral exposure (≥ 0)
      immunisationDose - the magnitude of immunizing exposure (≥ 0)
      Returns:
      a new instance of the model advanced by one time step
